description: 2020 JUN 05-- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Chemicals& Chemistry Business Daily Business Daily Daily-- From Washington, D.C., NewsRx journalists report that a patent application by the inventors Alberti, Carlo; Gasparini, Alberto; Lacche, Tiziano, filed on January 21, 2020, was made available online on May 21, 2020. The patent’ s assignee is WHIRLPOOL EMEA...
text:
2020 JUN 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Chemicals &
Chemistry Business Daily Business Daily Daily \-- From Washington, D.C.,
NewsRx journalists report that a patent application by the inventors Alberti,
Carlo (Fabriano, IT); Gasparini, Alberto (Fabriano, IT); Lacche, Tiziano
(Matelica, IT), filed on January 21, 2020, was made available online on May
21, 2020.

The patent's assignee is WHIRLPOOL EMEA S.P.A. (Pero (MI), Italy).

News editors obtained the following quote from the background information
supplied by the inventors: "At present, several typologies of cooking tops are
available on the market, the most widespread typology using one or more gas
burners, wherein the amount of heat necessary for cooking food is generated
through combustion of a gas appropriately mixed with air.

"Systems of burners are also known in the art, which have a substantially
circular shape and have two concentric burners, typically an outer burner and
an inner burner.

"Such systems of burners are known as 'double-crown', and include gas supply
means, said supply means comprising, for example, a pair of gas inlet ducts
associated with independent control valves, so that the two burners (i.e. the
outer burner and the inner burner) can be used either together or separately
in order to achieve good variability and a homogeneous distribution of the
heat to be supplied to the cooking containers. As an alternative, both
concentric burners may be fed by a single gas inlet duct, with an associated
tap, which simultaneously feeds the different intake channels that supply the
air-gas mixture to the concentric burners.

"Such systems of burners further include a cup comprising at least one first
chamber for supplying the air-gas mixture to the inner burner and at least one
second chamber for supplying said air-gas mixture to the outer burner, said
cup being associated with the supply means and with at least one flame divider
(or cap).

"The cup and the flame divider may be positioned on the cooking top where the
system of burners is installed, and use the air above the cooking top as
primary air to be mixed with the gas.

"Also, the cup is usually made of die-cast aluminum, while the flame divider
or cap is usually made of enameled cast iron (or brass alloy or steel) and
acts as a cup closing element.

"These systems of burners known in the art typically propagate a flame known
as 'crown flame'; a 'crown flame' is a flame with a substantially radial
direction of propagation, i.e., a flame that propagates outwards from the gas
burner in a substantially radial direction with respect to the burner axis,
and therefore in a direction which is substantially tangential to a visible
surface of the cooking top. Said 'crown flame', when emitted at an
insufficient height above the cooking top, may cause low-CO.sub.2 combustion,
resulting in the generation of a high level of unburnt products (CO and
NO.sub.x).

"Systems of burners are also known in the art which have a flame divider or
cap with a plurality of apertures adapted to generate a 'carpet flame', i.e.,
a flame that propagates out of the system of burners in a substantially axial
direction with respect to the axis of the system of burners, and therefore in
a direction which is substantially orthogonal to a visible surface of the
cooking top.

"A carpet flame may be a total carpet flame or a perimetric carpet flame,
depending on whether it covers a geometric figure (generally a circle)
entirely or just the peripheral portion of said geometric figure (generally a
circular crown).

"Also in the case of a perimetric carpet flame, a plurality of concentric rows
of apertures can generate a 'carpet flame', in particular for the purpose of
optimally heating also the central portion of the base of a cooking vessel
positioned over the gas burner.

"However, the solutions known in the art suffer from a few drawbacks.

"In particular, in the solutions known in the art, the components of the
system of burners are substantially made by die casting, being typically made
of die-cast aluminum alloys; it is clear that this solution is an expensive
one, and therefore a cooking top comprising such a system of burners will
implement solutions that are not very effective in economical terms.

"Furthermore, in the solutions known in the art, the flame divider is
positioned flush with the visible surface of the cooking top. When the system
of burners is in use, it has been noticed that such a realization may cause
overheating of that area of the visible surface of the cooking top which is
closest to the system of burners; it is clear that this overheating may also
cause damages to the cooking top, particularly when the latter is made from
glassy materials or the like."

As a supplement to the background information on this patent application,
NewsRx correspondents also obtained the inventors' summary information for
this patent application: "It is an object of the present device to provide a
system of gas burners, in particular for a cooking top for household use, and
an associated cooking top which are adapted to overcome the drawbacks of
prior-art solutions.

"Consequently, it is one object of the present device to provide a system of
gas burners and an associated cooking top which are so realized as to prove
particularly efficient and economical.

"In particular, it is one object of the present device to provide a system of
gas burners which is so realized as to ensure optimal gas efficiency while at
the same time lowering its production costs.

"It is another object of the present device to provide a system of gas burners
which is so realized as to prevent overheating of the region of the cooking
top proximal to the system of burners, and to avoid possible damage to the
cooking top, particularly when the latter is made from glassy materials or the
like.

"Said objects are achieved by the present device through a system of gas
burners, in particular for a cooking top for household use, and an associated
cooking top incorporating the features set out in the appended claims, which
are intended to be an integral part of the present description."

The claims supplied by the inventors are:

"1\. A gas burner for a cooktop, the gas burner comprising: an outer burner
having a first base and a first flame divider; an inner burner having a second
base and a second flame divider; first and second supplies of gas that are
delivered to the outer and inner burners, respectively, and wherein the first
and second supplies of gas are separated from one another by the outer and
inner burners; at least one arm that extends between the outer and inner
burners and includes ignition apertures that place the outer burner and the
first supply of gas in communication with the inner burner and the second
supply of gas, the ignition apertures configured to propagate a flame between
the outer and inner burners and within an area above the at least one arm,
wherein: the first and second flame dividers having first apertures and second
apertures, respectively; the first and second apertures extending
substantially parallel to a common central axis of the outer and inner
burners; and the ignition apertures extend proximate each of the first and
second apertures.

"2\. The gas burner of claim 1, wherein the first and second supplies of gas
are confined to the first and second bases, respectively.

"3\. The gas burner of claim 1, wherein the at least one arm extends over the
first and second bases.

"4\. The gas burner of claim 1, wherein the outer and inner burners are
concentric circles that are aligned with the common central axis.

"5\. The gas burner of claim 2, wherein the first base of the outer burner
includes a first Venturi element adapted to receive the first supply of gas
from a first injector, and a first duct for supplying the first supply of gas
to the first base, and wherein the second base of the inner burner includes a
second Venturi element adapted to receive the second supply of gas from a
second injector, and a second duct for supplying the second supply of gas to
the second base.

"6\. The gas burner of claim 5, wherein the first base of the outer burner is
positioned so that the first duct enters a substantially toroidal portion
having at least one aperture for passage of the first supply of gas.

"7\. The gas burner of claim 5, wherein an assembly having the second Venturi
element and the second duct is substantially pipe shaped.

"8\. The gas burner of claim 5, wherein primary air is delivered from below
the cooking top proximate at least one first air intake of the first base and
at least one second air intake of the second base to allow entry of primary
air, and wherein the first and second air intakes are located upstream of the
first Venturi element and of the second Venturi element, respectively.

"9\. The gas burner of claim 1, wherein the first base includes a first half
body and a second half body each made from sheet metal and joined together,
said second base including a first half shell and a second half shell each
made from a metallic sheet and joined together.

"10\. The gas burner of claim 1, wherein the first flame divider, the second
flame divider and the at least one arm are made from a single metallic member
that is one of a metal sheet and a metal-alloy sheet.

"11\. A burner comprising: an outer burner having a first burner body and a
first flame divider, the outer burner receiving a first supply of gas from a
first gas duct; an inner burner having a second burner body and a second flame
divider, the inner burner receiving a second supply of gas from a second gas
duct, the first supply of gas being separate from the second supply of gas;
and an arm that extends between the first and second flame dividers, wherein:
the first flame divider and the second flame divider are in communication with
one another above the first and second flame dividers via a plurality of
ignition apertures defined within the arm; the outer and inner burners are
concentrically positioned relative to a common central axis; the first flame
divider, the second flame divider and the arm are part of a single integral
piece that extends over each of the outer and inner burners; and the first
flame divider and second flame divider include first and second apertures,
respectively, and the plurality of ignition apertures extend proximate each of
the first and second apertures.

"12\. The burner of claim 11, wherein the first supply of gas is confined to
the outer burner and the second supply of gas is confined to the inner burner.

"13\. The burner of claim 11, wherein the first burner body and second burner
body are joined together by at least one bridge.

"14\. The burner of claim 11, wherein the first flame divider, the second
flame divider and the arm are made from a single metallic member that is one
of a metal sheet and a metal-alloy sheet.

"15\. The burner of claim 11, wherein the first flame divider includes a side
wall that positions the first apertures in a raised position relative to the
cooking top, the side wall having a height in a range of 10 millimeters to 20
millimeters.

"16\. The burner of claim 15, wherein the height of the side wall is 15
millimeters.

"17\. The burner of claim 15, wherein the first burner body includes a flank,
the flank having a flank height substantially similar to that of the height of
the side wall, wherein coupling of the first burner body and the first flame
divider defines a seal that substantially prevents the first supply of gas
from escaping in a generally lateral direction, and wherein the flank of the
first burner body and the side wall of the first flame divider are arranged
substantially adjacent and substantially parallel in an operating condition of
the inner and outer burners.

"18\. A gas burner comprising: an outer burner having a first flame divider;
an inner burner having a second flame divider, wherein the outer burner is
configured to receive a first supply of gas from a first gas duct and the
inner burner is configured to receive a second supply of gas from a second gas
duct, and wherein the first and second supplies of gas are separated within
outer and inner burners, respectively; and an arm that extends between the
first and second burners and having ignition apertures that place the outer
burner and the first supply of gas in communication with the inner burner and
the second supply of gas above the outer and inner burners, wherein: the first
flame divider, the second flame divider and the arm are incorporated within a
single metallic member that propagates a flame between the outer and inner
burners within an area above the arm; and the first and second flame dividers
include first and second apertures, respectively, and the ignition apertures
extend proximate each of the first and second apertures.

"19\. The gas burner of claim 18, wherein the first flame divider includes a
side wall that positions the first apertures in a raised position relative to
the cooking top, the side wall having a height in a range of 10 millimeters to
20 millimeters.

"20\. The gas burner of claim 19, wherein the height of the side wall is 15
millimeters."

For additional information on this patent application, see: Alberti, Carlo;
Gasparini, Alberto; Lacche, Tiziano. System Of Gas Burners, In Particular For
A Cooking Top For Household Use. Filed January 21, 2020 and posted May 21,
2020. Patent URL: [http://appft.uspto.gov/netacgi/nph-
Parser?Sect1=PTO1&Sect2=HITOFF&d=PG01&p=1&u=%2Fnetahtml%2FPTO%2Fsrchnum.html&r=1&f=G&l=50&s1=%2220200158345%22.PGNR.&OS=DN/20200158345&RS=DN/20200158345](http://appft.uspto.gov/netacgi/nph-
Parser?Sect1=PTO1&Sect2=HITOFF&d=PG01&p=1&u=%2Fnetahtml%2FPTO%2Fsrchnum.html&r=1&f=G&l=50&s1=%2220200158345%22.PGNR.&OS=DN/20200158345&RS=DN/20200158345)

title: Researchers Submit Patent Application, “System Of Gas Burners, In Particular For A Cooking Top For Household Use”, for Approval (USPTO 20200158345): WHIRLPOOL EMEA S.P.A.
html:
2020 JUN 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Chemicals & Chemistry Business Daily Business Daily Daily -- From Washington, D.C., NewsRx journalists report that a patent application by the inventors Alberti, Carlo (Fabriano, IT); Gasparini, Alberto (Fabriano, IT); Lacche, Tiziano (Matelica, IT), filed on January 21, 2020, was made available online on May 21, 2020.

The patent’s assignee is WHIRLPOOL EMEA S.P.A. (Pero (MI), Italy).

News editors obtained the following quote from the background information supplied by the inventors: “At present, several typologies of cooking tops are available on the market, the most widespread typology using one or more gas burners, wherein the amount of heat necessary for cooking food is generated through combustion of a gas appropriately mixed with air.

“Systems of burners are also known in the art, which have a substantially circular shape and have two concentric burners, typically an outer burner and an inner burner.

“Such systems of burners are known as ‘double-crown’, and include gas supply means, said supply means comprising, for example, a pair of gas inlet ducts associated with independent control valves, so that the two burners (i.e. the outer burner and the inner burner) can be used either together or separately in order to achieve good variability and a homogeneous distribution of the heat to be supplied to the cooking containers. As an alternative, both concentric burners may be fed by a single gas inlet duct, with an associated tap, which simultaneously feeds the different intake channels that supply the air-gas mixture to the concentric burners.

“Such systems of burners further include a cup comprising at least one first chamber for supplying the air-gas mixture to the inner burner and at least one second chamber for supplying said air-gas mixture to the outer burner, said cup being associated with the supply means and with at least one flame divider (or cap).

“The cup and the flame divider may be positioned on the cooking top where the system of burners is installed, and use the air above the cooking top as primary air to be mixed with the gas.

“Also, the cup is usually made of die-cast aluminum, while the flame divider or cap is usually made of enameled cast iron (or brass alloy or steel) and acts as a cup closing element.

“These systems of burners known in the art typically propagate a flame known as ‘crown flame’; a ‘crown flame’ is a flame with a substantially radial direction of propagation, i.e., a flame that propagates outwards from the gas burner in a substantially radial direction with respect to the burner axis, and therefore in a direction which is substantially tangential to a visible surface of the cooking top. Said ‘crown flame’, when emitted at an insufficient height above the cooking top, may cause low-CO.sub.2 combustion, resulting in the generation of a high level of unburnt products (CO and NO.sub.x).

“Systems of burners are also known in the art which have a flame divider or cap with a plurality of apertures adapted to generate a ‘carpet flame’, i.e., a flame that propagates out of the system of burners in a substantially axial direction with respect to the axis of the system of burners, and therefore in a direction which is substantially orthogonal to a visible surface of the cooking top.

“A carpet flame may be a total carpet flame or a perimetric carpet flame, depending on whether it covers a geometric figure (generally a circle) entirely or just the peripheral portion of said geometric figure (generally a circular crown).

“Also in the case of a perimetric carpet flame, a plurality of concentric rows of apertures can generate a ‘carpet flame’, in particular for the purpose of optimally heating also the central portion of the base of a cooking vessel positioned over the gas burner.

“However, the solutions known in the art suffer from a few drawbacks.

“In particular, in the solutions known in the art, the components of the system of burners are substantially made by die casting, being typically made of die-cast aluminum alloys; it is clear that this solution is an expensive one, and therefore a cooking top comprising such a system of burners will implement solutions that are not very effective in economical terms.

“Furthermore, in the solutions known in the art, the flame divider is positioned flush with the visible surface of the cooking top. When the system of burners is in use, it has been noticed that such a realization may cause overheating of that area of the visible surface of the cooking top which is closest to the system of burners; it is clear that this overheating may also cause damages to the cooking top, particularly when the latter is made from glassy materials or the like.”

As a supplement to the background information on this patent application, NewsRx correspondents also obtained the inventors’ summary information for this patent application: “It is an object of the present device to provide a system of gas burners, in particular for a cooking top for household use, and an associated cooking top which are adapted to overcome the drawbacks of prior-art solutions.

“Consequently, it is one object of the present device to provide a system of gas burners and an associated cooking top which are so realized as to prove particularly efficient and economical.

“In particular, it is one object of the present device to provide a system of gas burners which is so realized as to ensure optimal gas efficiency while at the same time lowering its production costs.

“It is another object of the present device to provide a system of gas burners which is so realized as to prevent overheating of the region of the cooking top proximal to the system of burners, and to avoid possible damage to the cooking top, particularly when the latter is made from glassy materials or the like.

“Said objects are achieved by the present device through a system of gas burners, in particular for a cooking top for household use, and an associated cooking top incorporating the features set out in the appended claims, which are intended to be an integral part of the present description.”

The claims supplied by the inventors are:

“1. A gas burner for a cooktop, the gas burner comprising: an outer burner having a first base and a first flame divider; an inner burner having a second base and a second flame divider; first and second supplies of gas that are delivered to the outer and inner burners, respectively, and wherein the first and second supplies of gas are separated from one another by the outer and inner burners; at least one arm that extends between the outer and inner burners and includes ignition apertures that place the outer burner and the first supply of gas in communication with the inner burner and the second supply of gas, the ignition apertures configured to propagate a flame between the outer and inner burners and within an area above the at least one arm, wherein: the first and second flame dividers having first apertures and second apertures, respectively; the first and second apertures extending substantially parallel to a common central axis of the outer and inner burners; and the ignition apertures extend proximate each of the first and second apertures.

“2. The gas burner of claim 1, wherein the first and second supplies of gas are confined to the first and second bases, respectively.

“3. The gas burner of claim 1, wherein the at least one arm extends over the first and second bases.

“4. The gas burner of claim 1, wherein the outer and inner burners are concentric circles that are aligned with the common central axis.

“5. The gas burner of claim 2, wherein the first base of the outer burner includes a first Venturi element adapted to receive the first supply of gas from a first injector, and a first duct for supplying the first supply of gas to the first base, and wherein the second base of the inner burner includes a second Venturi element adapted to receive the second supply of gas from a second injector, and a second duct for supplying the second supply of gas to the second base.

“6. The gas burner of claim 5, wherein the first base of the outer burner is positioned so that the first duct enters a substantially toroidal portion having at least one aperture for passage of the first supply of gas.

“7. The gas burner of claim 5, wherein an assembly having the second Venturi element and the second duct is substantially pipe shaped.

“8. The gas burner of claim 5, wherein primary air is delivered from below the cooking top proximate at least one first air intake of the first base and at least one second air intake of the second base to allow entry of primary air, and wherein the first and second air intakes are located upstream of the first Venturi element and of the second Venturi element, respectively.

“9. The gas burner of claim 1, wherein the first base includes a first half body and a second half body each made from sheet metal and joined together, said second base including a first half shell and a second half shell each made from a metallic sheet and joined together.

“10. The gas burner of claim 1, wherein the first flame divider, the second flame divider and the at least one arm are made from a single metallic member that is one of a metal sheet and a metal-alloy sheet.

“11. A burner comprising: an outer burner having a first burner body and a first flame divider, the outer burner receiving a first supply of gas from a first gas duct; an inner burner having a second burner body and a second flame divider, the inner burner receiving a second supply of gas from a second gas duct, the first supply of gas being separate from the second supply of gas; and an arm that extends between the first and second flame dividers, wherein: the first flame divider and the second flame divider are in communication with one another above the first and second flame dividers via a plurality of ignition apertures defined within the arm; the outer and inner burners are concentrically positioned relative to a common central axis; the first flame divider, the second flame divider and the arm are part of a single integral piece that extends over each of the outer and inner burners; and the first flame divider and second flame divider include first and second apertures, respectively, and the plurality of ignition apertures extend proximate each of the first and second apertures.

“12. The burner of claim 11, wherein the first supply of gas is confined to the outer burner and the second supply of gas is confined to the inner burner.

“13. The burner of claim 11, wherein the first burner body and second burner body are joined together by at least one bridge.

“14. The burner of claim 11, wherein the first flame divider, the second flame divider and the arm are made from a single metallic member that is one of a metal sheet and a metal-alloy sheet.

“15. The burner of claim 11, wherein the first flame divider includes a side wall that positions the first apertures in a raised position relative to the cooking top, the side wall having a height in a range of 10 millimeters to 20 millimeters.

“16. The burner of claim 15, wherein the height of the side wall is 15 millimeters.

“17. The burner of claim 15, wherein the first burner body includes a flank, the flank having a flank height substantially similar to that of the height of the side wall, wherein coupling of the first burner body and the first flame divider defines a seal that substantially prevents the first supply of gas from escaping in a generally lateral direction, and wherein the flank of the first burner body and the side wall of the first flame divider are arranged substantially adjacent and substantially parallel in an operating condition of the inner and outer burners.

“18. A gas burner comprising: an outer burner having a first flame divider; an inner burner having a second flame divider, wherein the outer burner is configured to receive a first supply of gas from a first gas duct and the inner burner is configured to receive a second supply of gas from a second gas duct, and wherein the first and second supplies of gas are separated within outer and inner burners, respectively; and an arm that extends between the first and second burners and having ignition apertures that place the outer burner and the first supply of gas in communication with the inner burner and the second supply of gas above the outer and inner burners, wherein: the first flame divider, the second flame divider and the arm are incorporated within a single metallic member that propagates a flame between the outer and inner burners within an area above the arm; and the first and second flame dividers include first and second apertures, respectively, and the ignition apertures extend proximate each of the first and second apertures.

“19. The gas burner of claim 18, wherein the first flame divider includes a side wall that positions the first apertures in a raised position relative to the cooking top, the side wall having a height in a range of 10 millimeters to 20 millimeters.

“20. The gas burner of claim 19, wherein the height of the side wall is 15 millimeters.”
